result.markdown:
--- title: "Using rgl to make 3D graphs in R" self-contained-math: true --- ## Introduction Understand and use the tutorial at , and other `rgl` vignettes. ## Setting up R Packages ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(rgl) options(rgl.useNULL = TRUE) # Suppress the separate window. knitr::knit_hooks$set(webgl = hook_webgl) rgl::setupKnitr(autoprint = TRUE) # To ensure embedding happens in the rendered page ``` ::: ## What is `rgl`? - 3D graphics library in R - High-level graphics modelled after base/classic-R graphics ### Functions in `rgl` 1. `plot3D` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ## Default method x <- penguins$bill_len y <- penguins$bill_dep z <- penguins$body_mass # target variable on z-axis open3d() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` glX 1 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} plot3d(x, y, z, col = as.numeric(penguins$species)) rglwidget() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} close3d() ``` ::: #### Adding Shapes to an existing 3D plot Let us add a regression plane to this plot. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Linear model fit <- lm(z ~ x + y) coefs <- coef(fit) a <- coefs["x"] b <- coefs["y"] c <- -1 d <- coefs["(Intercept)"] open3d() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` glX 3 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} plot3d(x, y, z, col = as.numeric(penguins$species), size = 4) planes3d(a, b, c, d, alpha = 0.2, color = "#D95F02") # lines3d(x = c(mean(x,na.rm = T), mean(x,,na.rm = T) + 10), # y = c(mean(y,,na.rm = T), mean(y,,na.rm = T) + 10), # z = c(mean(z,na.rm = T), mean(z,na.rm = T) + 10)) arrow3d( p0 = c(mean(x, na.rm = T), mean(y, , na.rm = T), mean(z, na.rm = T)), p1 = c( mean(x, na.rm = T) + a / 10, mean(y, , na.rm = T) + b / 10, mean(z, na.rm = T) + c / 10 ), width = 0.05, type = "ext", s = 0.08 ) # rgl::axes3d(x, y, z) # Show tick marks # axis3d('x', pos=c( NA, 0, 0 ), col = "darkgrey") # axis3d('y', pos=c( 0, NA, 0 ), col = "darkgrey") # axis3d('z', pos=c( 0, 0, NA ), col = "darkgrey") decorate3d(xlab = "Bill Length", ylab = "Bill Depth", zlab = "Body Mass") rglwidget() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} close3d() ``` ::: 2. `persp3D` This creates a perspective / mesh plot of a function. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- seq(-10, 10, length.out = 20) y <- x f <- function(x, y) { r <- sqrt(x^2 + y^2) 10 * sin(r) / r } z <- outer(x, y, f) # Needs a matrix, like a carpet with bumps z[is.na(z)] <- 1 open3d() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` glX 5 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} persp3d(x, y, z, aspect = c(1, 1, 0.5), col = "dodgerblue", xlab = "X", ylab = "Y", zlab = "Sinc( r )", polygon_offset = 1, smooth = TRUE, ambient = "black", specular = "white", shininess = 2.5 ) # Overlay perspective plots persp3d(x, y, z, front = "lines", back = "lines", add = TRUE) rglwidget() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} close3d() ``` ::: 3. `dot3d, wire3d, shade3d` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- rnorm(20) y <- rnorm(20) open3d() points3d(x, y, front = "points", back = "points") rglwidget() close3d() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` glX 1 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: 3. turn3D: Making solids of rotation ## References 1. How to embed `rgl` generated plots in Quarto HTML.
